Abstract  Glucocorticoids: examples of translational medicine; from molecular aspects to bedside.
 Glucocorticoids 	are 	anti-inflammatory, 	immunosuppressant 	and 	anti-allergic 	drugs 	derived 	from 	hy-
drocortisone. 	Their	widespread 	use	was	originated 	from	Hench’s	observations 	in	patients	with	rheumatoid 	arthritis.	
These	drugs 	are 	examples 	of 	translational 	medicine 	and 	they 	can 	be 	envisaged 	as 	one 	of 	the 	most 	prescribed 	
and	feared 	drugs. 	The 	objective 	of 	this 	review 	is 	to 	highlight 	their 	pharmacological 	properties 	and 	thus, 	allow 	a	
more	suitable 	prescription.
